channel.title: BBC News - Science & Environment

item.title: Milky Way galaxy is warped and twisted, not flat
item.description: New research shows our galaxy, the Milky Way, is twisted and warped - not flat as previously thought.

item.title: AI system 'should be recognised as inventor'
item.description: Two patent filings seek to set a precedent by naming an AI as their inventor.

item.title: Climate change: UK's 10 warmest years all occurred since 2002
item.description: The patterns of warm and cold years in Britain are a clear signal of climate change, say scientists.

item.title: Whale 'swallows' sea lion: 'It was a once-in-a-lifetime event'
item.description: Wildlife photographer Chase Dekker took the photos while whale watching in California.

item.title: Ethiopia 'breaks' tree-planting record to tackle climate change
item.description: More than 350 million trees have been planted in a single day to tackle deforestation, officials say.

item.title: Ghana 'exports rosewood timber illegally to China'
item.description: Corrupt officials are forging documents to allow the wood to leave the country, environmentalists say.

item.title: Drug-resistant superbug spreading in Europe's hospitals
item.description: Scientists are "extremely concerned" by a bacterium resistant to antibiotics of last resort.

item.title: Spanish slugs: Moscow alarm over giant invasive pests
item.description: Voracious Arion vulgaris slugs have spread across Europe from Spain and are major pests.

item.title: India tiger census shows rapid population growth
item.description: PM Narendra Modi says India is "now one of the biggest and most secure habitats of the tiger".

item.title: Greta Thunberg to sail Atlantic for climate conferences
item.description: Malizia II, a high-speed yacht built to race around the world, will take the teen activist to the US.

item.title: UK heatwave: Met Office confirms record temperature in Cambridge
item.description: Thursday's 38.7C in Cambridge is the hottest day ever recorded in the UK, the Met Office says.

item.title: Plastic pollution: Cycle-challenge woman 'speechless' at beach waste
item.description: Kiko Matthews, who cycled around the UK coast, says she collected 3.45 tonnes of rubbish from beaches.

item.title: No-deal Brexit 'threatens' UK science industry, says Wellcome Trust
item.description: Wellcome Trust chairwoman warns Boris Johnson that Britain will lose out if it "amputates" the EU.

item.title: Arctic wildfires: What's caused huge swathes of flames to spread?
item.description: The fires are releasing significant amounts of carbon gases, further contributing to global warming.

item.title: Tim Flannery: Climate change - very big and fast moving
item.description: Tim Flannery, chief councillor of Climate Council Australia, warns about the pace of climate change.

item.title: Proms pay space-aged tribute to Nasa engineer Christopher Kraft
item.description: Chris Kraft, who founded Nasa's mission control, is honoured at the Proms after his death this week.

item.title: Dinosaur bone: Scientists uncover giant femur in France
item.description: The two-metre long femur is thought to have belonged to a sauropod from the late Jurassic era.

item.title: Hawaii TMT: Desecrating sacred land or finding new frontiers?
item.description: Plans for a powerful new telescope on a sacred site in Hawaii have created rifts among islanders.

item.title: Climate change: Current warming 'unparalleled' in 2,000 years
item.description: The speed and extent of global warming exceeds any similar event in the past two millennia, researchers say.

item.title: Greta Thunberg speech: French MPs boycott teen ‘apocalypse guru’
item.description: The teen activist is ridiculed by some French MPs ahead of her speech to parliament.

item.title: Nasa Moon lander vision takes shape
item.description: Nasa has outlined more details of its plans for a landing craft that will take humans to the Moon's surface in the 2020s.

item.title: Chris Kraft: Key Apollo 11 director dies days after anniversary
item.description: Nasa's first flight director played a critical role in the first Moon landing 50 years ago.

item.title: 'Restore UK bogs' to tackle climate change
item.description: Restoring peat moors degraded by farming may prove a relatively inexpensive way of tackling climate change.

item.title: 'Important' Iron Age settlement found at Warboys dig
item.description: Roman and early Saxon finds were also discovered at the settlement, which was previously unknown.

item.title: Chandrayaan-2: India launches second Moon mission
item.description: The $145m Chandrayaan-2 aims to become the first space mission to land on the Moon's south pole.

item.title: Women in science: Smashing glass ceilings and glass walls
item.description: From pushing boundaries to defying stereotypes - five women who are breaking barriers in science.

item.title: Russia alarmed by large fall in bee populations
item.description: Pesticides are blamed for Russia's mass bee deaths, while French honey production is also down.

item.title: Big Butterfly Count: Which common UK species to look for
item.description: The public is being urged to spend 15 minutes in a sunny spot for the world's biggest butterfly survey.

item.title: Vast sand scheme to protect Norfolk coast
item.description: Nearly two million cubic metres of sand is being shifted to a stretch of the Norfolk coast to protect it from the sea.

item.title: Iceland pilot whales: Dozens of dead mammals found beached
item.description: The pilot whales were spotted during a helicopter sightseeing tour over Longufjorur.

item.title: River Stour runs dry in drought in Constable Country
item.description: The Environment Agency takes steps to refill a river featured in some of the UK's best-loved paintings.

item.title: World experienced hottest June on record in 2019, says US agency
item.description: The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says the average temperature was 61.6F (16.4C).

item.title: Cigarette butts in soil hamper plant growth, study suggests
item.description: A study suggests the butts make up the most pervasive form of plastic pollution on the planet.

item.title: Red List: Extinction threat to overlooked species
item.description: Fish, snails and fungi join a list of threatened species, as conservationists say small, slimy species have been overlooked.

item.title: Johnson and Hunt told no-deal Brexit 'threat to research'
item.description: The Royal Society tells the Tory leadership candidates the UK collaborates more with the EU than the US.

item.title: Bioluminescent plankton hunters capture 'magical' glow
item.description: Photographers and nature lovers capture the natural phenomenon that lights up the sea.

item.title: Israel mosque find: Archaeologists unearth 1,200-year-old ruins in desert
item.description: Researchers say the mosque, dating from the 7th or 8th century, would be a rare find anywhere.

item.title: Climate change: 'No brainer' fuel change to cut transport carbon
item.description: MPs say the simple step of adding more ethanol to the UK's fuel mix would be same as taking 700,000 cars off the roads.

item.title: Bloodhound Diary: All roads lead to South Africa
item.description: The British-based land speed record team is heading to Northern Cape to conduct high-speed trials.

item.title: Genetic testing: What secrets could it reveal about you?
item.description: Genome sequencing projects around the world are revealing promising new health insights.

item.title: What's a 'Science Princess' doing in Alaska?
item.description: Celeste Labedz's picture of herself dressed up as a princess while on a field trip researching glaciers has become a viral hit.

item.title: Trump straws: How the US president is using straws to beat liberals with
item.description: Why Trump is selling plastic straws at $15 a pack - and using them as a stick to beat liberals with.

item.title: Why is India sending humanoid robots into space?
item.description: India will fly robots to understand what weightlessness and radiation do to the human body in space.

item.title: Car parts from weeds: The future of green motoring?
item.description: The motor industry is trying to reduce its carbon footprint in a number of innovative ways.

item.title: The horrific consequences of rubber's toxic past
item.description: The appalling treatment of Congo's rubber workers led to the world's first photographic human rights campaign.

item.title: Sounding alert about vanishing US coastlines
item.description: A new photography book captures the environmental threat to America's coastal region.

item.title: Russia's Sirius Moon project leaves crew hungry for steak
item.description: Four Russians and two Nasa engineers emerge from four months in a Moscow "spacecraft".

item.title: Should I offset my summer holiday flights?
item.description: As more of us worry about our carbon emissions, how can you offset your air travel?

item.title: Extinction Rebellion: Who are they and what are their aims?
item.description: The Extinction Rebellion group is holding climate protests across the UK.

item.title: Mumbai rains: Is India's weather becoming more extreme?
item.description: With Mumbai seeing its heaviest rain in a decade, Reality Check looks at India's extreme weather patterns.

item.title: Artificial lionfish powered by ‘robotic blood’
item.description: The circulatory system fitted to the synthetic fish allows it to be powered for about 40 hours.

item.title: Predator Free 2050: New Zealand ramps up plan to purge all pests
item.description: New Zealand digs in with its controversial plan to protect native species by wiping out all predators.

item.title: Why blue jeans are going green
item.description: A growing number of denim producers are embracing environmentally-friendly production methods.

item.title: Taking Nasa's space buggies for a spin
item.description: BBC Click's Spencer Kelly takes a ride in some in some of Nasa's latest vehicles.

item.title: Northern white rhino hope after artificial insemination birth
item.description: A southern white rhino has given birth after artificial insemination, raising hopes for the northern white rhino population.

item.title: Nasa’s Valkyrie robot could help build Mars base
item.description: The semi-autonomous robot is able to use human tools and guide itself across difficult terrain.

item.title: Why is it so hot and is climate change to blame?
item.description: Weather experts say a shift in the position of the jet stream is behind Europe's high temperatures.

item.title: Stopping child marriage with solar lanterns
item.description: Girls in Ethiopia are being given solar lamps to help stop child marriage and keep them in school.
